elements.content: Chiral crystalline sponges with preinstalled chiral references were synthesized. On the basis of the known configurations of the chiral references, the absolute structures of guest compounds absorbed in the pores of the crystalline sponges can be reliably determined without crystallization or chemical modification.
elements.clean_text: Chiral crystalline sponges with preinstalled chiral references were synthesized. On the basis of the known configurations of the chiral references, the absolute structures of guest compounds absorbed in the pores of the crystalline sponges can be reliably determined without crystallization or chemical modification.

elements.content: Absolute configuration determination is the most important yet probably the most difficult structure analysis of organic small molecules. Single-crystal X-ray analysis is one of the only methods that can directly determine absolute configurations without any chiral references by observing the anomalous scattering effect, commonly from heavy atoms involved in analyte molecules (the Bijvoet method). However, this absolute method is not always practical because of the need to prepare high-quality single crystals of analytes and also for synthetic loads for incorporating heavy atom(s) when the anomalous scattering from the chiral guest is weak.
elements.clean_text: Absolute configuration determination is the most important yet probably the most difficult structure analysis of organic small molecules. Single-crystal X-ray analysis is one of the only methods that can directly determine absolute configurations without any chiral references by observing the anomalous scattering effect, commonly from heavy atoms involved in analyte molecules (the Bijvoet method). However, this absolute method is not always practical because of the need to prepare high-quality single crystals of analytes and also for synthetic loads for incorporating heavy atom(s) when the anomalous scattering from the chiral guest is weak.

elements.content: The crystalline sponge (CS) method is an emerging X-ray technique that does not require sample crystallization. This method has recently been utilized to determine the absolute configurations of chiral compounds. Since heavy (iodine) atoms are already installed in the host framework as ZnI2 metal nodes, incorporation of heavy atoms into the guest analytes is unnecessary. However, to observe effective anomalous scattering from the host, the initial achiral space group (C2/c) must be altered to a chiral space group (C2 or P21) through efficient chirality transfer from the guest to the host. This requirement limits the method to be applicable only to guests that show strong host–guest interactions with a high site occupancy (normally >80%).
elements.clean_text: The crystalline sponge (CS) method is an emerging X-ray technique that does not require sample crystallization. This method has recently been utilized to determine the absolute configurations of chiral compounds. Since heavy (iodine) atoms are already installed in the host framework as ZnI2 metal nodes, incorporation of heavy atoms into the guest analytes is unnecessary. However, to observe effective anomalous scattering from the host, the initial achiral space group (C2/c) must be altered to a chiral space group (C2 or P21) through efficient chirality transfer from the guest to the host. This requirement limits the method to be applicable only to guests that show strong host-guest interactions with a high site occupancy (normally >80%).

elements.content: To overcome this limitation, in this work we designed a chiral CS in which a chiral reference is preinstalled in the host framework. We show that the absolute configuration of the guest is easily and reliably determined by observing the relative configurations of the guest with respect to the chiral reference preinstalled in the chiral CS. Yaghi and co-workers have recently reported a chiral MOF available for the absolute structure determination of postabsorbed chiral guests, but the chirality of the host is unknown and has to be judged from the diffraction data. Our chiral CS contains a chiral reference of known configuration, and the guest configuration can be determined more reliably by simply comparing its relative configuration to that of the chiral reference.
elements.clean_text: To overcome this limitation, in this work we designed a chiral CS in which a chiral reference is preinstalled in the host framework. We show that the absolute configuration of the guest is easily and reliably determined by observing the relative configurations of the guest with respect to the chiral reference preinstalled in the chiral CS. Yaghi and co-workers have recently reported a chiral MOF available for the absolute structure determination of postabsorbed chiral guests, but the chirality of the host is unknown and has to be judged from the diffraction data. Our chiral CS contains a chiral reference of known configuration, and the guest configuration can be determined more reliably by simply comparing its relative configuration to that of the chiral reference.

elements.content: The chiral CS [(ZnI2)3(tpt)2·(G*)] n (1) (tpt = 2,4,6-tris­(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine; G* = (S,S)-2 or (R,R)-2) was prepared by “plug-in” synthesis, in which a variety of functional groups can be embedded within the host network by plugging in functionalized triphenylenes (a). Layer diffusion of a methanol solution of ZnI2 into a PhNO2/MeOH solution of the tpt ligand and (S,S)-2 gave yellow needlelike crystals formulated as {[(ZnI2)3(tpt)2·(S,S)-2]·(PhNO2)5·(MeOH)} n in 34% yield. Nitrobenzene that fills the pores was completely replaced with less coordinating solvents such as cyclohexane or n-hexane to facilitate the subsequent guest soaking. The solvent-exchanged CS (S,S)-1 was fully characterized by elemental analysis, IR, and X-ray diffraction studies (see the Supporting Information (SI)). The structure of (S,S)-1 was solved in the noncentrosymmetric space group P212121. (S,S)-1 has two types of one-dimensional channels: triangular and rectangular channels (pores A and B in b). In a similar fashion, enantiomeric (R,R)-1 was also synthesized as yellow needles in 37% yield.
elements.clean_text: The chiral CS [(ZnI2)3(tpt)2⋅(G*)] n  (1) (tpt = 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine; G* = (S,S)-2 or (R,R)-2) was prepared by "plug-in" synthesis, in which a variety of functional groups can be embedded within the host network by plugging in functionalized triphenylenes (a). Layer diffusion of a methanol solution of ZnI2 into a PhNO2/MeOH solution of the tpt ligand and (S,S)-2 gave yellow needlelike crystals formulated as {[(ZnI2)3(tpt)2⋅(S,S)-2]⋅(PhNO2)5⋅(MeOH)} n  in 34% yield. Nitrobenzene that fills the pores was completely replaced with less coordinating solvents such as cyclohexane or n-hexane to facilitate the subsequent guest soaking. The solvent-exchanged CS (S,S)-1 was fully characterized by elemental analysis, IR, and X-ray diffraction studies (see the Supporting Information (SI)). The structure of (S,S)-1 was solved in the noncentrosymmetric space group P212121. (S,S)-1 has two types of one-dimensional channels: triangular and rectangular channels (pores A and B in b). In a similar fashion, enantiomeric (R,R)-1 was also synthesized as yellow needles in 37% yield.

elements.content: (a) Synthesis of chiral CS 1. (b) Top view of the X-ray crystal structure of (S,S)-1. The host framework is shown in gray. The chiral reference (S,S)-2 (orange) is embedded in the host (gray) through columnar stacking. Solvent molecules have been omitted for clarity. (c) Side view of the columnar stacking (inset part of (b)).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Synthesis of chiral CS 1. (b) Top view of the X-ray crystal structure of (S,S)-1. The host framework is shown in gray. The chiral reference (S,S)-2 (orange) is embedded in the host (gray) through columnar stacking. Solvent molecules have been omitted for clarity. (c) Side view of the columnar stacking (inset part of (b)).

elements.content: Dimethyl l-(+)-tartrate (3) was included into the pores of (S,S)-1 by soaking a single crystal (0.12 mm × 0.19 mm × 0.20 mm) of (S,S)-1 in a cyclohexane (45 μL)/CH2Cl2 (5 μL) solution of 3 (10 μg). After slow evaporation of the solvent at 50 °C over 2 days, the resulting inclusion complex (S,S)-1·3 was subjected to single-crystal X-ray analysis. The crystal structure revealed four guest 3 molecules, one of which was trapped in pores A with 100% occupancy. On the basis of the known stereochemistry of the chiral reference (S,S)-2, the absolute configuration of (+)-3 was confirmed to be 2R,3R (). It is worth noting that in this case the absolute configuration of (2R,3R)-3 was also confirmed from the anomalous scattering (Flack parameter (Parsons) = 0.024(4)).
elements.clean_text: Dimethyl l-(+)-tartrate (3) was included into the pores of (S,S)-1 by soaking a single crystal (0.12 mm × 0.19 mm × 0.20 mm) of (S,S)-1 in a cyclohexane (45 μL)/CH2Cl2 (5 μL) solution of 3 (10 μg). After slow evaporation of the solvent at 50 °C over 2 days, the resulting inclusion complex (S,S)-1⋅3 was subjected to single-crystal X-ray analysis. The crystal structure revealed four guest 3 molecules, one of which was trapped in pores A with 100% occupancy. On the basis of the known stereochemistry of the chiral reference (S,S)-2, the absolute configuration of (+)-3 was confirmed to be 2R,3R (). It is worth noting that in this case the absolute configuration of (2R,3R)-3 was also confirmed from the anomalous scattering (Flack parameter (Parsons) = 0.024(4)).

elements.content: (a) X-ray structure of (S,S)-1·(2R,3R)-3. The analyte (2R,3R)-3 and the chiral reference (S,S)-1 plugged into the host framework are highlighted in color. (b) ORTEP drawing of (2R,3R)-3. Thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level. Its R,R configuration was confirmed by comparing the relative configuration to that of the chiral reference (S,S)-1.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) X-ray structure of (S,S)-1⋅(2R,3R)-3. The analyte (2R,3R)-3 and the chiral reference (S,S)-1 plugged into the host framework are highlighted in color. (b) ORTEP drawing of (2R,3R)-3. Thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level. Its R,R configuration was confirmed by comparing the relative configuration to that of the chiral reference (S,S)-1.

elements.content: Since CS 1 is chiral, the two enantiomers of any chiral guest should show different absorption behavior because of their diastereomeric relationship with respect to the chiral reference. Thus, the two enantiomers of menthol (4) were subjected to chiral CS analysis. When (−)-4 was included in (S,S)-1, the guests were observed in both pores A and pores B by X-ray diffraction (a). Two guest molecules in pores A were found in an asymmetric unit with occupancies of 100% and 64%.
elements.clean_text: Since CS 1 is chiral, the two enantiomers of any chiral guest should show different absorption behavior because of their diastereomeric relationship with respect to the chiral reference. Thus, the two enantiomers of menthol (4) were subjected to chiral CS analysis. When (-)-4 was included in (S,S)-1, the guests were observed in both pores A and pores B by X-ray diffraction (a). Two guest molecules in pores A were found in an asymmetric unit with occupancies of 100% and 64%.

elements.content: X-ray crystal structures of (a) (S,S)-1·(1R,2S,5R)-4 and (b) (S,S)-1·(1S,2R,5S)-4. Samples for the diffraction study were prepared by guest soaking of enantiomers (−)-4 and (+)-4 with (S,S)-1, respectively. The conformations of the two enantiomers are slightly different because of their diastereomeric relationship to the chiral reference (S,S)-1. Guests are observed in both pores A and pores B in (S,S)-1·(1R,2S,5R)-4 (with occupancies of 100% and 77% respectively), whereas they are in only pores A in (S,S)-1·(1S,2R,5S)-4 with 100% occupancy. The guest and the chiral reference are highlighted in color, one pair being presented as a space-filling model. Thermal ellipsoids are set at the 50% probability level.
elements.clean_text: 3  X-ray crystal structures of (a) (S,S)-1⋅(1R,2S,5R)-4 and (b) (S,S)-1⋅(1S,2R,5S)-4. Samples for the diffraction study were prepared by guest soaking of enantiomers (-)-4 and (+)-4 with (S,S)-1, respectively. The conformations of the two enantiomers are slightly different because of their diastereomeric relationship to the chiral reference (S,S)-1. Guests are observed in both pores A and pores B in (S,S)-1⋅(1R,2S,5R)-4 (with occupancies of 100% and 77% respectively), whereas they are in only pores A in (S,S)-1⋅(1S,2R,5S)-4 with 100% occupancy. The guest and the chiral reference are highlighted in color, one pair being presented as a space-filling model. Thermal ellipsoids are set at the 50% probability level.

elements.content: One guest engages with a nearby iodine atom in ZnI2 with an O···I distance of 3.123 Å. In pores B, one slightly disordered guest with occupancy of 77% was observed in close proximity to the dioxolane substituent of (S,S)-2 with an O···O distance of 2.926 Å. By comparison of the relative stereochemistry with that of reference (S,S)-2, the absolute configuration of (−)-4 was clearly determined to be (1R,2S,5R)-4. The enantiomer (+)-4 was also included in (S,S)-1 but trapped with a slightly different conformation in pores A (b). Notably, no guest in pores B nor any guest interaction with the dioxolane substituent of (S,S)-2 was observed with (+)-4. The observation of different binding modes in the diastereomeric pairs of (S,S)-1·(−)-4 and (S,S)-1·(+)-4 clearly shows the discrimination of the chirality of (−)-4 and (+)-4 by the chiral pores of 1. For further confirmation of this chiral discrimination, we analyzed the structure of (+)-4 with the host (R,R)-1 (see the SI). As expected, (R,R)-1·(+)-4 revealed the exact mirror-image structure of (S,S)-1·(−)-4. In all cases, reasonable Flack parameter values (Parsons) were obtained (<0.06), and the absolute stereochemistries of the guests were also confirmed by the Bijvoet method.
elements.clean_text: One guest engages with a nearby iodine atom in ZnI2 with an O⋅⋅⋅I distance of 3.123 Å. In pores B, one slightly disordered guest with occupancy of 77% was observed in close proximity to the dioxolane substituent of (S,S)-2 with an O⋅⋅⋅O distance of 2.926 Å. By comparison of the relative stereochemistry with that of reference (S,S)-2, the absolute configuration of (-)-4 was clearly determined to be (1R,2S,5R)-4. The enantiomer (+)-4 was also included in (S,S)-1 but trapped with a slightly different conformation in pores A (b). Notably, no guest in pores B nor any guest interaction with the dioxolane substituent of (S,S)-2 was observed with (+)-4. The observation of different binding modes in the diastereomeric pairs of (S,S)-1⋅(-)-4 and (S,S)-1⋅(+)-4 clearly shows the discrimination of the chirality of (-)-4 and (+)-4 by the chiral pores of 1. For further confirmation of this chiral discrimination, we analyzed the structure of (+)-4 with the host (R,R)-1 (see the SI). As expected, (R,R)-1⋅(+)-4 revealed the exact mirror-image structure of (S,S)-1⋅(-)-4. In all cases, reasonable Flack parameter values (Parsons) were obtained (<0.06), and the absolute stereochemistries of the guests were also confirmed by the Bijvoet method.

elements.content: Furthermore, we applied this method to the absolute configuration analysis of sugar derivative 5, as sugars are one of the most difficult classes of compounds to analyze crystallographically. Empirical configuration analysis by the Mosher method is hard to apply to sugars because of signal overlap in the NMR analysis. After protection of the 2,3- and 4,5-diol groups, d-fructopyranose was subjected to chiral CS analysis with (S,S)-1, and its 2S,3S,4R,5R configuration was confirmed ().
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, we applied this method to the absolute configuration analysis of sugar derivative 5, as sugars are one of the most difficult classes of compounds to analyze crystallographically. Empirical configuration analysis by the Mosher method is hard to apply to sugars because of signal overlap in the NMR analysis. After protection of the 2,3- and 4,5-diol groups, d-fructopyranose was subjected to chiral CS analysis with (S,S)-1, and its 2S,3S,4R,5R configuration was confirmed ().

elements.content: X-ray crystal structure of (2S,3S,4R,5R)-5 determined by chiral CS analysis (occupancy: 54%). Thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level.
elements.clean_text: 4  X-ray crystal structure of (2S,3S,4R,5R)-5 determined by chiral CS analysis (occupancy: 54%). Thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level.

elements.content: In combination with chiral HPLC analysis, chiral CS 1 provides a means of chiral liquid chromatography–single-crystal diffraction (LC–SCD) analysis for facile and reliable absolute structure determination. A prochiral ketone, phenacyl azide, was reduced to a racemic mixture of the enantiomers of 2-azido-1-phenylethanol (rac-6) by NaBH4 reduction. When the crude reaction product, rac-6 (100 μg), was subjected to chiral HPLC analysis, the two enantiomers were separated with retention times of 32.3 and 34.6 min (column: CHIRALPAK IC; solvent: hexane/iPrOH = 99/1; flow rate: 0.5 mL/min at 25 °C). The first and second fractions showed positive and negative circular dichroism (CD) signals, respectively, at 254 nm (a). The first fraction was examined by chiral CS analysis with (S,S)-1. In the asymmetric unit, four guest molecules of 6 were observed, two of which directly interact with (S,S)-2 through a hydrogen bond with HO···O distances of 1.94 and 2.41 Å (b). The absolute configuration of the first fraction was thus reliably determined to be R (c, left). The S configuration for the second fraction was also confirmed by X-ray analysis using (R,R)-1 (c, right). In a similar way, a racemic mixture of the enantiomers of 4-bromo-α-methylbenzyl alcohol (rac-7), obtained from NaBH4 reduction of 4′-bromoacetophenone, was analyzed by chiral HPLC. The first fraction collected (t ret = 58.3 min) was deduced to be (R)-7 using (S,S)-1 as the chiral CS, and second fraction (t ret = 64.0 min) was assigned to be (S)-7 using (R,R)-1 (d).
elements.clean_text: In combination with chiral HPLC analysis, chiral CS 1 provides a means of chiral liquid chromatography-single-crystal diffraction (LC-SCD) analysis for facile and reliable absolute structure determination. A prochiral ketone, phenacyl azide, was reduced to a racemic mixture of the enantiomers of 2-azido-1-phenylethanol (rac-6) by NaBH4 reduction. When the crude reaction product, rac-6 (100 μg), was subjected to chiral HPLC analysis, the two enantiomers were separated with retention times of 32.3 and 34.6 min (column: CHIRALPAK IC; solvent: hexane/iPrOH = 99/1; flow rate: 0.5 mL/min at 25 °C). The first and second fractions showed positive and negative circular dichroism (CD) signals, respectively, at 254 nm (a). The first fraction was examined by chiral CS analysis with (S,S)-1. In the asymmetric unit, four guest molecules of 6 were observed, two of which directly interact with (S,S)-2 through a hydrogen bond with HO⋅⋅⋅O distances of 1.94 and 2.41 Å (b). The absolute configuration of the first fraction was thus reliably determined to be R (c, left). The S configuration for the second fraction was also confirmed by X-ray analysis using (R,R)-1 (c, right). In a similar way, a racemic mixture of the enantiomers of 4-bromo-α-methylbenzyl alcohol (rac-7), obtained from NaBH4 reduction of 4'-bromoacetophenone, was analyzed by chiral HPLC. The first fraction collected (t ret = 58.3 min) was deduced to be (R)-7 using (S,S)-1 as the chiral CS, and second fraction (t ret = 64.0 min) was assigned to be (S)-7 using (R,R)-1 (d).

elements.content: (a) HPLC chromatogram of rac-6 (black, UV absorption at 210 nm; red, CD signal at 254 nm). (b) X-ray structure of (S,S)-1·(R)-6. A sample for the diffraction study was prepared by guest soaking of the first fraction from the HPLC purification into (S,S)-1. The guest (two molecules) and the chiral reference in one pore are highlighted in color. (c) Left: ORTEP drawing of (R)-6 found in the (S,S)-1·(R)-6 structure (occupancy: 100%). Right: ORTEP drawing of (S)-6 found in the (R,R)-1·(S)-6 structure (occupancy: 94%). (d) Left: ORTEP drawing of (R)-7 found in the (S,S)-1·(R)-7 structure (occupancy: 82%). The analyte (R)-7 was obtained as the first fraction of the chiral HPLC purification. Right: ORTEP drawing of (S)-7 found in the (R,R)-1·(S)-7 structure (occupancy: 86%). The analyte (S)-7 was obtained as the second fraction of the chiral HPLC purification. Thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) HPLC chromatogram of rac-6 (black, UV absorption at 210 nm; red, CD signal at 254 nm). (b) X-ray structure of (S,S)-1⋅(R)-6. A sample for the diffraction study was prepared by guest soaking of the first fraction from the HPLC purification into (S,S)-1. The guest (two molecules) and the chiral reference in one pore are highlighted in color. (c) Left: ORTEP drawing of (R)-6 found in the (S,S)-1⋅(R)-6 structure (occupancy: 100%). Right: ORTEP drawing of (S)-6 found in the (R,R)-1⋅(S)-6 structure (occupancy: 94%). (d) Left: ORTEP drawing of (R)-7 found in the (S,S)-1⋅(R)-7 structure (occupancy: 82%). The analyte (R)-7 was obtained as the first fraction of the chiral HPLC purification. Right: ORTEP drawing of (S)-7 found in the (R,R)-1⋅(S)-7 structure (occupancy: 86%). The analyte (S)-7 was obtained as the second fraction of the chiral HPLC purification. Thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level.

elements.content: In summary, a chiral CS with a preinstalled chiral reference has been developed and successfully used for the determination of the absolute configurations of chiral compounds by comparing the relative configurations of the reference and analyte compounds. The only requirement of our method is the concomitant observation of both chiral molecules (the reference and the analyte) in the crystal structure. This represents a great advantage over other commonly used relative methods, such as Mosher’s empirical method, the cocrystallization method, and sample derivatization with a chiral reference, in which close contact or efficient chiral interaction between the analyte and the reference is essential yet does not always promise successful determination of the absolute configuration. Because of the crystallization-free protocol, the applicability for trace-amount analysis, and more importantly, the high reliability of the relative method relayed to the known configuration of the chiral reference, the present chiral CS is expected to be one of the best tools for absolute configuration determination.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a chiral CS with a preinstalled chiral reference has been developed and successfully used for the determination of the absolute configurations of chiral compounds by comparing the relative configurations of the reference and analyte compounds. The only requirement of our method is the concomitant observation of both chiral molecules (the reference and the analyte) in the crystal structure. This represents a great advantage over other commonly used relative methods, such as Mosher's empirical method, the cocrystallization method, and sample derivatization with a chiral reference, in which close contact or efficient chiral interaction between the analyte and the reference is essential yet does not always promise successful determination of the absolute configuration. Because of the crystallization-free protocol, the applicability for trace-amount analysis, and more importantly, the high reliability of the relative method relayed to the known configuration of the chiral reference, the present chiral CS is expected to be one of the best tools for absolute configuration determination.

Absolute structure determination using Zn–tpt-based crystalline sponges:

Absolute structure determination using non-Zn–tpt-based crystalline sponges:

Inclusion experiments with menthol guests (4) take place preferentially using n-hexane over cyclohexane. A minimum number of restraints were applied on the guest frameworks throughout this study (see the SI).

A sample for the diffraction study was prepared by guest soaking of the first fraction from the HPLC purification into (S,S)-1. The guest (two molecules) and the chiral reference in one pore are highlighted in color. (c) Left: ORTEP drawing of (R)-6 found in the (S,S)-1⋅(R)-6 structure (occupancy: 100%). Right: ORTEP drawing of (S)-6 found in the (R,R)-1⋅(S)-6 structure (occupancy: 94%). (d) Left: ORTEP drawing of (R)-7 found in the (S,S)-1⋅(R)-7 structure (occupancy: 82%). The analyte (R)-7 was obtained as the first fraction of the chiral HPLC purification. Right: ORTEP drawing of (S)-7 found in the (R,R)-1⋅(S)-7 structure (occupancy: 86%). The analyte (S)-7 was obtained as the second fraction of the chiral HPLC purification. Thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level.

Chiral
Crystalline Sponges for the Absolute Structure
Determination of Chiral Guests
